summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, requesting permission to file sealed motions in limine in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The government seeks redactions to protect the privacy of victims and third parties.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge to whom the government's letter and sealing request regarding motions in limine in the Ghislaine Maxwell case is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) for which the government is submitting sealed motions in limine.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who is respectfully submitting the letter and sealing request to the court.

connections.description: Williams, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell.

events.title: Government Submits Sealed Motions in Limine
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office submits motions in limine under seal in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, requesting court permission to file them publicly with redactions.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government is seeking to file redacted versions of its motions in limine in the Ghislaine Maxwell prosecution.
The proposed redactions aim to protect the privacy of victims, including those who have not publicly identified themselves or appeared on the record.
The government also seeks to seal 'Section X' of the motions at least until the conclusion of the trial.
The legal justification for the sealing request is based on the Second Circuit's test in Lugosch v. Pyramid Co. of Onondaga.
